unnormalised: Educational achievements are a big deal in India, aren't they? From the moment we're born, it feels like the pressure's on to ace those exams and bag those degrees. Everyone from your dadi to your chacha seems to have an opinion on which course is the "best" and how many marks you should be scoring. It's all a bit much, tbh.
normalised: Educational achievements are a big deal in India, aren't they? From the moment we're born, it feels like the pressure's on to ace those exams and bag those degrees. Everyone from your dadi to your chacha seems to have an opinion on which course is the "best" and how many marks you should be scoring. It's all a bit much, to be honest.

unnormalised: So, you finally got your 10th marksheet from CBSE with a score of 90%. Congrats! But the real climb starts now, right? Next up is that 12th board exam, and then deciding whether you're going to be an Engg (Engineering) or a Dr. (Doctor). All this while trying to figure out if you even like any of it!
normalised: So, you finally got your tenth marksheet from C-B-S-E with a score of ninety percent. Congrats! But the real climb starts now, right? Next up is that twelfth board exam, and then deciding whether you're going to be an Engineer (Engineering) or a Doctor (Doctor). All this while trying to figure out if you even like any of it!

unnormalised: And what about all the extra certifications? Everyone seems to be doing a course on something – AI, Data Science, Digital Marketing. Suddenly, just a plain old B.Com (Bachelor of Commerce) doesn't seem enough. I remember my cousin, Priya, stressing over her NPTEL certification while simultaneously studying for her CA exams. Double the pressure, double the fun (not really!).

I remember my cousin, Priya, stressing over her N-P-T-E-L certification while simultaneously studying for her C-A exams. Double the pressure, double the fun (not really!).

unnormalised: Let's not forget the dreaded entrance exams! JEE for engineering, NEET for medicine, CLAT for law... the list goes on. My neighbour's son, Rakesh, spent 2 whole years prepping for IIT-JEE. He even got a rank of 5000-ish. Huge achievement, but the stress was insane. These exams are like a rite of passage, aren't they?
normalised: Let's not forget the dreaded entrance exams! J-E-E for engineering, N-E-E-T for medicine, C-L-A-T for law... the list goes on. My neighbor's son, Rakesh, spent two whole years prepping for I-I-T-J-E-E. He even got a rank of five thousand-ish. Huge achievement, but the stress was insane. These exams are like a rite of passage, aren't they?

unnormalised: Then comes the Master's degree dilemma. Should you go for an MBA from IIM-A or stick to your field and get an M.Tech from IIT-B? The choices seem endless, and each one comes with its own set of challenges. And of course, the pressure from family to land a "good" job after all that studying.
normalised: Then comes the Master's degree dilemma. Should you go for an M-B-A from I-I-M-A or stick to your field and get an M-Tech from I-I-T-B? The choices seem endless, and each one comes with its own set of challenges. And of course, the pressure from family to land a "good" job after all that studying.

unnormalised: Ultimately, it's about finding what truly makes you happy, isn't it? Sure, a degree from Oxford or a PhD can open doors, but it's your passion and skills that will take you further. So, whether you're rocking a simple BA from Delhi University or a fancy MS from Stanford, remember to keep learning and growing. Good luck, folks!
